The Chiefs of Staff reported the principal events of thepast week.It had only been possible to bomb Germany on two nightsduring the previous week. On the night of the 17th / 18th December49 bombers had attacked targets in North-West Germany. Theintention had been that our aircraft should fly below the clouds. Itwould appear that many aircraft had not done this, and 17 had been lost. The matter was being investigated. On the previous nighta successful attack had been made by 230 bombers on Duisburg.Fighter Command on the previous day had supported a heavy attack by United States Fortresses and Liberators on Romilly. Inday attacks on the South Coast during the week the enemy had lost11 machines destroyed, 2 probably destroyed and 11 damaged. total enemy losses in the Home Theatre had been 15 aircraft destroyed,3 probably destroyed and 13 damaged. Our losses had been2 fighters, 33 bombers and 8 Coastal Command aircraft destroyed.In the attack on Romilly the United States air force had lost,6 Fortresses. The fighting had been heavy and the United Statesbombers had inflicted severe losses. The assessment Was not yetcomplete. The first claims were 45 aircraft destroyed and26 probably destroyed.Our air effort in North Africa had more than doubled duringthe previous week, whilst that of the enemy had fallen off. enemy losses had been 43 aircraft destroyed, and ours 20 destroyed and4 damaged.During a heavy night attack on Malta .7 of our aircraft hadbeen destroyed on the ground. Enemy losses for the week had been17 aircraft destroyed, 8 probably destroyed and 10 damaged. our losses had been 6 aircraft, excluding those destroyed on the ground.In Cyrenaica there had been little air opposition.Including belated reports, shipping losses for the previous week amounted to 82,000 tons.Further stores had been landed at Malta, which was nowprovisioned until the end of April.Our submarines in the Mediterranean had sunk 1 U-boat, a destroyer and 7 merchant ships. In addition, possibly 3 otherU-boats had been sunk.Enemy attempts to land reinforcements in Southern new guinea had failed.There had been little change in the positions held by our forcesin Tunisia during the previous week.The Chief of the Imperial General Staff undertook tofurnish the Prime Minister with a detailed analysis of the tanks which were to accompany the 11th armoured division if it were sent overseas.The Prime Minister read out a telegram from general eisenhower which referred to the effect of dive-bombing attacks on some of the troops in this area.The Chief of the Imperial General Staff was requested toobtain further information from General Anderson on thismatter.The chief event of the week had been the successful turningmovement by which the New Zealand Division had got across theline of retreat of Rommel's rearguard from Agheila. In confusedfighting we had taken 500 prisoners and 30 guns and destroyed20 tanks. Our advance forces had now reached Es Sultan.Our forces were advancing on Akyab. The operations in this area were not oh such a large scale as had been represented in thePress. ,In the Pacific theatre during the past week the Japanese had.been on the defensive.The Russian offensive in the Middle Don area reported in the newspapers that morning had great possibilities. The main attack had been on a 50-mile front with a-subsidiary attack on a 13-mile[24805]B 2 front. The enemy troops engaged consisted mainly of Italians. TheRussians had also had successes at Tuapse and in the Caucasus. Theposition on the whole Russian front appeared to be most satisfactory.The War Cabinet took note of these statements.Air Policy. 2. The War.Cabinet were informed that representations hadbeen made by Sir Walter Citrine on behalf of Senor RodriguezVega, formerly Secretary-General of the Spanish Workers' Union,who had been persuaded to leave Spain and was now at Lisbon.Senor Vega desired to proceed eventually to Mexico, but it wassuggested that he should be allowed to come to this country in thefirst instance. He was an associate of Dr. Negrin, who was anxiousto meet him in this country. If he were allowed to come here, this fact would undoubtedly be used to our disadvantage in enemy propaganda. It was probably true that his life would be in dangerif he remained in Lisbon; but it would be preferable that we'should do what we could to facilitate his journey from Lisbon to Mexicorather than enable him to travel to this country.The War Cabinet-Invited the Foreign Secretary (1) To take such steps as he could to ensure that SefiorVega was given facilities to proceed from Lisbonto Mexico at the earliest possible date.(2) To inform Sir Walter Citrine that, while HisMajesty's Government thought it undesirable inpresent circumstances that Senor Vega should visitthis country, they were using their good offices tosecure for him an early passage from Lisbon toMexico.Prisoners of(previous reference erence:W.M. To date one of the seemingly obvious lessons of thiscampaign is that, in general practice,we are far behind theenemy in the amounts of light flak made available to groundtroops and forward aerodromes. This relative deficiencyshows up with particular effect because of the comparativegreenness of our troops. Our experience to date shows thatthe dive bomber, unless through our own carlessness ithappens to encounter a most vulnerable target, has much,greater moral than material effect. Actual personnel lossesresulting from this form of attack are quite moderate; butas a preliminary to tank and infantry advances' againstcomparatively raw troops, it is quite devastating. Our ownairplanes, attempting to operate at low altitude over enemyground forces and aerodromes, invariably encounter severeflak and a high rate of casualty. On the other hand we havebeen far less successful in this regard and this factcreates among ground forces an insistent demand for aso-called air umbrella. Normally the Air Force cannotprovide this and. still execute essential tasks in defeatingthe enemy fighters and long range bombers and in escortingour own bombers.2. I recommend that these matters be given the mostearnest attention, not only in all training programs but inthe matter of devising appropriate equipment and includingit in strong percentage in all combat formations. For staticdefense, of aerodromes and other fixed.installations the effort should be to provide a maximum of weapons with a,minimum of personnel and with mounts so designed that some protection to operating personnel can be quickly providedthrough digging of pits or throwing up of revetments. In thisconnection the anti aircraft weapon on fixed mount in halftrack is so exposed, particularly in barren, country, thatoperating personnel apparently has to become seasoned before 'it will/
asoned before/it will stick by the weapon, and operate it effectively.All personnel must be indoctrinated with the conviction that the best defense against a low.flying plane is awell directed and intense volume of fire from everyavailable weapon. It appears that when the enemy'slosses- begin to mount he will be reluctant to undertake this particular' type of attack according to experiencedairmen.RELAYED TO AGWAR BYSIG CEN.CirculationBrigadier JacobForg i gn S secretary.irst Sea Lord.6.'
